__e: Mr. Bannister, I have a message for you from the staff of the hotel.
After 6 p.m., when the Observatory's personnel had left, we were allowed to leave the room, but at 8 a.m. we had to be back.
You may not speak to hotel employees. You must go through me.
I saw every employee that works here, no matter how insignificant.
I have an employee who does all that now.
It's every employee that works for me.
So besides the list of employees you gave us, you can't think of anyone else who might have wanted to hurt her?
Dexter, are there any employees you haven't seen over the last few days?
So, confined to a room much like the one you described, tended to only by the parents or perhaps a trusted servant, that boy or girl would spend their lives, however long those might be.
I employ hundreds of people. They have to be paid tomorrow.
And then? You dismiss the staff and we both wait here.
This is the part where you play the employee, and I play the boss.
I have no interest in doing the same with my employees.
I reserve the right to dismiss my employees as I see fit.
You'd think they'd have a hard time holding on to their employees.
You'll see. My employees are so happy working here, they hate to stay home on Sundays!
Excuse me, Mr. Mayor, but 7 of your staffers are dead and others severely injured.
